title: 114_s2392
content: The Act titled "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" limits the removal of Medicare Advantage providers by MA organizations. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" limits MA organizations from removing providers without cause starting in 2017. Providers can only be removed if they are medically negligent or violate legal or contractual requirements. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" restricts MA organizations from removing providers without cause starting in 2017. Providers can only be removed if they are medically negligent or violate legal or contractual requirements, including participation or other requirements under the title or contractual terms for the plan. Cost to the MA organization due to a provider's participation in the network is not a valid reason for mid-year removal. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" prohibits MA organizations from removing providers without cause starting in 2017. Providers can only be removed for medical negligence or violations of legal or contractual requirements. Cost to the MA organization is not a valid reason for mid-year removal. Removal can only occur after a fair notice and appeal process established by the Secretary. The Secretary shall establish a fair notice and appeal process for MA organizations to remove providers from their network, with reasons required for removal. This process applies to removals occurring after the effective date specified in a final rule, replacing the previous termination process. The process for removing a provider from an MA plan network before the effective date involves following the termination or suspension process outlined in federal regulations. Participants must be notified at least 60 days in advance of the provider's removal from the network. The notification of provider removal from an MA plan network must include names and contact information of alternative in-network providers, options for continuing treatment with the removed provider, and customer support information. The MA organization offering an MA plan must provide customer service telephone numbers for individuals to access information about network changes. Additionally, the organization must include removal notifications in the annual notice of change and ensure continuity of care when a provider is removed from the network. Beginning with plan year 2017, MA organizations offering an MA plan must provide transparency in the measures used to establish or modify provider networks. This information must be included in the annual bid information submitted by the organization and on the MA plan's website. This does not affect a provider's ability to decline participation in an MA plan network. Beginning with plan year 2017, MA organizations offering an MA plan must provide transparency in the measures used to establish or modify provider networks. This information, including quality and efficiency measures, must be included in the annual bid information and on the MA plan's website. The information provided should not include any individually identifiable information of providers or suppliers. Enforcement measures, including sanctions for noncompliance, are outlined in Section 1857(g)(1) of the plan. Enforcement measures for MA organizations not complying with provider network transparency requirements are outlined in Section 1857(g)(1) of the Social Security Act. Sanctions include penalties for failing to comply with specific sections of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must ensure that the Medicare Advantage Compare Tool considers the preferences and utilization needs of individuals within one year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. NETWORK ADEQUACY. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors like enrollment, services provided, provider availability, and location when establishing a plan network. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must ensure timely provision of care by providers and adhere to network access adequacy standards set by the Secretary. Providers' availability, location, and certification are key factors to consider. Providers' availability, location, and certification are key factors to consider. Each plan year, Medicare Advantage organizations are required to report average wait times, utilization of out-of-network providers, and average cost per patient for primary and specialty care under the plan. In advance of the annual coordinated election period, Medicare Advantage organizations must certify the accuracy of provider directories for each plan offered. The Secretary ensures network adequacy guidelines are met at least once every 3 years or when a material change in network occurs. Enforcement includes amendments to the Social Security Act. The Secretary enforces network adequacy guidelines for Medicare Advantage organizations, requiring certification of provider directories before the annual coordinated election period. Amendments to the Social Security Act are made for enforcement purposes.
